description: From Middle English replicacioun, replicacion, from Anglo-Norman replicacioun and Old French replicacion (“reply, answer”), from Latin replicātiō, replicātiōnem.

entries.meaning: The process by which an object, person, place or idea may be copied mimicked or reproduced.
examples: DNA replication is the process of producing two identical replicas from one original DNA molecule.
That painting is an almost exact replication of a famous Rembrandt painting.

entries.meaning: (law) A response from the plaintiff to the defendant's plea.
(biology) The process of producing replicas of DNA or RNA molecules.

(computing) The process of frequent electronic data copying a one database in one computer or server to a database in another so that all users share the same level of information. Used to improve fault tolerance of the system.
